awd_titl_txt: Educating the Next Generation of Quantum Computing Developers
awd_abstract_narration:
The NSF's Accelerating Discovery: Educating the Future STEM Workforce supports efforts that can position the future STEM workforce to make bold advances in the NSF Big Ideas (https://www.nsf.gov/about/congress/115/10bigideas.jsp). This Accelerating Discovery project will support the Quantum Leap and the Work at the Human-Technology Frontier Big Ideas by developing a research-focused undergraduate program in quantum computing and quantum information science. Quantum computing is one of the fastest growing technology fields to emerge in the 21st century. Over the last thirty years, it has grown from an abstract idea to demonstrated hardware rivaling the best supercomputers for selected problems. This project is designed to educate the next generation of STEM workers for this evolving field. It is critical to engage these students' interest early in their careers before they are lost to more established fields. Without STEM workers who are trained in quantum computing, our nation would be at a competitive disadvantage compared to countries that are now investing heavily in these areas. This project aims to recruit and prepare the next generation of quantum computing developers. It will do so by building upon and expand a pilot program begun in 2018 at The University of Texas at Austin to introduce incoming first-year students to quantum computing and quantum information science. 

The project will be conducted as part of the University of Texas at Austin's successful Freshman Research Initiative, which provides entering first-year students with a unique research-oriented learning experience. Participation in the Freshman Research Initiative has been demonstrated to improve student performance and increase participation of students in STEM, including students from groups that are underrepresented in many STEM fields. The project will build upon the success of the 2018 pilot by developing a more comprehensive program that integrates the first-year student experience with upper division coursework and senior projects. These courses and experiences will be integrated into a certificate program in quantum computing, which will provide graduating students with the training and formal recognition needed to launch a career in quantum technology. This project will assess the impact of the quantum computing education on student development and persistence in the sciences, using assessment instruments and strategies developed for the Freshmen Research Initiative. The goal of this assessment will be to determine which specific aspects of the certificate program contribute most to improved student performance in STEM majors. This project will produce a body of instructional material and impact analysis focusing on early post-secondary STEM students who have little-to-no prior knowledge of quantum physics or quantum computing. The intended result is a unique program in quantum computing that can be scaled to a national level. The curricular materials developed in the project will be included in a Massively Open Online Course available through edX, to support access to the public and adoption by other institutions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Quantum technologies are expected to revolutionize the fields of computing, communication, and sensing.  Quantum sensors will have the ability to measure to unbelievable precision, quantum networks are now being built to provide secure and trusted communication across the world, and future quantum computers promise to provide a massive leap forward in our ability to solve the world?s most challenging computational problems.  The science behind these powerful new technologies can appear strange and mysterious, and for decades quantum physics has required years of specialized training to master.  This approach is simply inadequate to prepare the next generation of quantum technologists.

The goal of this project was to build the tools, materials, and techniques to train the future quantum workforce.  As such, we focused on first-year undergraduate students, most of whom have had no formal training in quantum physics.  Our work was predicated on the belief that such students could not only grasp the basic concepts but master the techniques sufficiently to contribute to ongoing research and development efforts.  Our results bore this out, and we consider the project an immense success.

From an initial pilot in the spring of 2018 with 14 students, we expanded under this grant to a full-year program with over 30 students enrolled each year.  Developed within the University of Texas at Austin (UT) Freshman Research Initiative (FRI) program, would students enter in the spring of their first year and continue in the program through the fall.  Several students also participated in an optional summer program focused on experimental quantum optics.  A combination of active learning, just-in-time instruction, and project-based group activities were used to take students from zero prior knowledge to full mastery of advanced subjects by the end of the year. 

The last three years have seen an explosion in the growth of quantum education.  Through the support of this grant we have been engaged from the very beginning in efforts to build a supportive and growing community of educators focused on introducing a new generation of students to the wonders of quantum physics and quantum technology.  We have participated in numerous workshops, conferences, and community meetings in an effort to learn from others, share our experiences, and disseminate instructional materials to our fellow educators.  Our entire spring and fall FRI courses on quantum computing are freely available through the Canvas Commons and can readily be adopted by anyone using compatible Learning Management Software.  The ease with which Canvas courses may be imported and used, either in their entirety or through individual modules, enables our work to scale to a world-wide audience.

Under this project we also created the first-ever certificate program for Quantum Information Science, which has since become a model for similar programs at other institutions.  A total of 156 students participated in the program, of which 28 have already been approved.  Several students have interned at quantum computing companies or have gone to pursue careers in quantum technology.  Within the university, a formal student association, the Quantum Collective, was created by former FRI students to provide a larger ecosystem of support and help students get involved in quantum through promoted hackathons, guest speakers, and other engagement activities.  The Collective now boasts over 60 registered student members and connects some 550 individuals through social media. 

Adapting to the COVID-19 pandemic, we developed a publicly accessible online simulation tool, the Virtual Quantum Optics Laboratory (VQOL), that allows students to design and execute realistic tabletop experiments in classical and quantum optics.  The VQOL software was designed by and for FRI students and was used during the pandemic when in-person laboratories were not available.  It has become a regular part of the FRI program and is now used in parallel with the in-person laboratory program.  VQOL has been widely disseminated outside of UT through workshops, seminars, publications, and shared instructional materials.  Academic researchers have also used VQOL to design and study new experiments or to conduct theoretical explorations of the quantum-classical boundary.

Our work has impacted high school instruction as well.  In 2019 we launched the first ever full-year high school course on quantum computing.  Based on the successful FRI stream, this pilot later transitioned in 2021 to a formal dual-enrollment course through the UT OnRamps program and is now available to high schools throughout the state of Texas.  Under the OnRamps program, students of participating schools are taught by a local teacher trained on materials developed by UT faculty and staff and are able to receive both high school and college credit at the same time.

The future of quantum technology looks very bright, and this grant has enabled a whole new generation of students to participate in its birth.  We look with great anticipation to the many wonders they will produce!
